prologue.scenelocation: Before an alehouse on a heath.

stagedir.dir: Enter beggar, Christophero Sly, and Hostess.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Third, or fourth, or fifth borough, I’ll answer him by law. I’ll not budge an inch, boy; let him come, and kindly.

stagedir.dir: Wind horns. Enter a Lord from hunting, with his Train.

prologue.line: Belike some noble gentleman that means
(Travelling some journey) to repose him here.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: Bid them come near. Now, fellows, you are welcome.

speech.speaker: ALL. PLAYERS.
speech.line: We thank your honor.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

speech.speaker: 2. PLAY.
speech.line: So please your lordship to accept our duty.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: With all my heart. This fellow I remember
Since once he play’d a farmer’s eldest son.
’Twas where you woo’d the gentlewoman so well.
I have forgot your name; but sure that part
Was aptly fitted and naturally perform’d.

speech.speaker: 1. PLAY.
speech.line: I think ’twas Soto that your honor means.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: ’Tis very true; thou didst it excellent.
Well, you are come to me in happy time,
The rather for I have some sport in hand,
Wherein your cunning can assist me much.
There is a lord will hear you play tonight;
But I am doubtful of your modesties,
Lest, over-eyeing of his odd behavior
(For yet his honor never heard a play),
You break into some merry passion,
And so offend him; for I tell you, sirs,
If you should smile, he grows impatient.

speech.speaker: 1. PLAY.
speech.line: Fear not, my lord, we can contain ourselves,
Were he the veriest antic in the world.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery,
And give them friendly welcome every one.
Let them want nothing that my house affords.
I know the boy will well usurp the grace,
Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman.
I long to hear him call the drunkard husband,
And how my men will stay themselves from laughter
When they do homage to this simple peasant.
I’ll in to counsel them; haply my presence
May well abate the over-merry spleen,
Which otherwise would grow into extremes.

prologue.scenelocation: A bedchamber in the Lord’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter aloft the drunkard Sly with Attendants, some with apparel, basin and ewer, and other appurtenances, and Lord.

prologue.line: And twenty caged nightingales do sing.
Or wilt thou sleep? We’ll have thee to a couch,
Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed
On purpose trimm’d up for Semiramis.
Say thou wilt walk; we will bestrow the ground.
Or wilt thou ride? Thy horses shall be trapp’d,
Their harness studded all with gold and pearl.
Dost thou love hawking? Thou hast hawks will soar
Above the morning lark. Or wilt thou hunt?
Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them
And fetch shrill echoes from the hollow earth.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: Say thou wilt course, thy greyhounds are as swift
As breathed stags; ay, fleeter than the roe.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV.
speech.line: Dost thou love pictures? We will fetch thee straight
Adonis painted by a running brook,
And Cytherea all in sedges hid,
Which seem to move and wanton with her breath,
Even as the waving sedges play with wind.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: We’ll show thee Io as she was a maid,
And how she was beguiled and surpris’d,
As lively painted as the deed was done.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV.
speech.line: Or Daphne roaming through a thorny wood,
Scratching her legs that one shall swear she bleeds,
And at that sight shall sad Apollo weep,
So workmanly the blood and tears are drawn.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord.
Thou hast a lady far more beautiful
Than any woman in this waning age.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee
Like envious floods o’errun her lovely face,
She was the fairest creature in the world,
And yet she is inferior to none.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Am I a lord, and have I such a lady?
Or do I dream? Or have I dream’d till now?
I do not sleep: I see, I hear, I speak;
I smell sweet savors, and I feel soft things.
Upon my life, I am a lord indeed,
And not a tinker, nor Christopher Sly.
Well, bring our lady hither to our sight,
And once again a pot o’ th’ smallest ale.

speech.speaker: 2. SERV.
speech.line: Will’t please your mightiness to wash your hands?
O how we joy to see your wit restor’d!
O that once more you knew but what you are!
These fifteen years you have been in a dream,
Or when you wak’d, so wak’d as if you slept.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: These fifteen years! By my fay, a goodly nap,
But did I never speak of all that time?

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: O yes, my lord, but very idle words,
For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,
Yet would you say ye were beaten out of door,
And rail upon the hostess of the house,
And say you would present her at the leet,
Because she brought stone jugs and no seal’d quarts.
Sometimes you would call out for Cicely Hacket.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Ay, the woman’s maid of the house.

speech.speaker: 3. SERV.
speech.line: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid,
Nor no such men as you have reckon’d up,
As Stephen Sly, and old John Naps of Greece,
And Peter Turph, and Henry Pimpernell,
And twenty more such names and men as these,
Which never were, nor no man ever saw.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!

speech.speaker: ALL. SERV. AND LORD.
speech.line: Amen.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Page as a lady, with Attendants.

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: Your honor’s players, hearing your amendment,
Are come to play a pleasant comedy,
For so your doctors hold it very meet,
Seeing too much sadness hath congeal’d your blood,
And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.
Therefore they thought it good you hear a play,
And frame your mind to mirth and merriment,
Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Marry, I will, let them play it. Is not a comonty a Christmas gambold, or a tumbling-trick?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: No, my good lord, it is more pleasing stuff.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: What, household stuff?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: It is a kind of history.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Well, we’ll see’t. Come, madam wife, sit by my side, and let the world slip, we shall ne’er be younger.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lucentio and his man Tranio.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am resolv’d you know:
That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter
Before I have a husband for the elder.
If either of you both love Katherina,
Because I know you well, and love you well,
Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: To cart her rather; she’s too rough for me.
There, there, Hortensio, will you any wife?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: And for I know she taketh most delight
In music, instruments, and poetry,
Schoolmasters will I keep within my house,
Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio,
Or, Signior Gremio, you, know any such,
Prefer them hither; for to cunning men
I will be very kind, and liberal
To mine own children in good bringing-up,
And so farewell. Katherina, you may stay,
For I have more to commune with Bianca.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: You may go to the devil’s dam; your gifts are so good, here’s none will hold you. Their love is not so great, Hortensio, but we may blow our nails together, and fast it fairly out. Our cake’s dough on both sides. Farewell; yet for the love I bear my sweet Bianca, if I can by any means light on a fit man to teach her that wherein she delights, I will wish him to her father.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: So will I, Signior Gremio. But a word, I pray. Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brook’d parle, know now upon advice, it toucheth us both, that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress, and be happy rivals in Bianca’s love, to labor and effect one thing specially.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: What’s that, I pray?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: A husband! A devil.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: I say, a husband.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I say, a devil. Think’st thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Tush, Gremio; though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, and a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I cannot tell; but I had as lief take her dowry with this condition: to be whipt at the high cross every morning.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Faith, as you say, there’s small choice in rotten apples. But come, since this bar in law makes us friends, it shall be so far forth friendly maintain’d till by helping Baptista’s eldest daughter to a husband we set his youngest free for a husband, and then have to’t afresh. Sweet Bianca, happy man be his dole! He that runs fastest gets the ring. How say you, Signior Gremio?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I am agreed, and would I had given him the best horse in Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her! Come on.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt ambo Gremio and Hortensio. Manent Tranio and Lucentio.

scene.line: Here comes the rogue. Sirrah, where have you been?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Where have I been? Nay, how now, where are you? Master, has my fellow Tranio stol’n your clothes? Or you stol’n his? Or both? Pray what’s the news?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Sirrah, come hither, ’tis no time to jest,
And therefore frame your manners to the time.
Your fellow Tranio here, to save my life,
Puts my apparel and my count’nance on,
And I for my escape have put on his;
For in a quarrel since I came ashore
I kill’d a man, and fear I was descried.
Wait you on him, I charge you, as becomes,
While I make way from hence to save my life.
You understand me?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Ay, sir!—
Ne’er a whit.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: And not a jot of Tranio in your mouth,
Tranio is chang’d into Lucentio.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: The better for him, would I were so too!

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after,
That Lucentio indeed had Baptista’s youngest daughter.
But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master’s, I advise
You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies.
When I am alone, why then I am Tranio;
But in all places else your master Lucentio.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Tranio, let’s go.
One thing more rests, that thyself execute—
To make one among these wooers. If thou ask me why,
Sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty.

speech.speaker: 1. SERV.
speech.line: My lord, you nod, you do not mind the play.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: Yes, by Saint Anne, do I. A good matter, surely; comes there any more of it?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: My lord, ’tis but begun.

speech.speaker: SLY.
speech.line: ’Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady; would ’twere done!

stagedir.dir: Enter Petruchio and his man Grumio.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter? My old friend Grumio! And my good friend Petruchio! How do you all at Verona?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray? Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato, may I say.

speech.speaker: HOR.

line.italian: Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio.

speech.line: Rise, Grumio, rise, we will compound this quarrel.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis no matter, sir, what he ’leges in Latin. If this be not a lawful cause for me to leave his service, look you, sir. He bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir. Well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so, being perhaps (for aught I see) two and thirty, a peep out?
Whom would to God I had well knock’d at first,
Then had not Grumio come by the worst.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: A senseless villain! Good Hortensio,
I bade the rascal knock upon your gate,
And could not get him for my heart to do it.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Knock at the gate? O heavens! Spake you not these words plain, “Sirrah, knock me here; rap me here; knock me well, and knock me soundly”? And come you now with “knocking at the gate”?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Sirrah, be gone, or talk not, I advise you.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Petruchio, patience, I am Grumio’s pledge.
Why, this’ a heavy chance ’twixt him and you,
Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.
And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale
Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Such wind as scatters young men through the world
To seek their fortunes farther than at home,
Where small experience grows. But in a few,
Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:
Antonio, my father, is deceas’d,
And I have thrust myself into this maze,
Happily to wive and thrive as best I may.
Crowns in my purse I have, and goods at home,
And so am come abroad to see the world.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee,
And wish thee to a shrewd ill-favor’d wife?
Thou’dst thank me but a little for my counsel;
And yet I’ll promise thee she shall be rich,
And very rich. But th’ art too much my friend,
And I’ll not wish thee to her.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we
Few words suffice; and therefore, if thou know
One rich enough to be Petruchio’s wife
(As wealth is burden of my wooing dance),
Be she as foul as was Florentius’ love,
As old as Sibyl, and as curst and shrewd
As Socrates’ Xantippe, or a worse,
She moves me not, or not removes at least
Affection’s edge in me. Whe’er she is as rough
As are the swelling Adriatic seas,
I come to wive it wealthily in Padua;
If wealthily, then happily in Padua.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Nay, look you, sir, he tells you flatly what his mind is. Why, give him gold enough, and marry him to a puppet or an aglet-baby, or an old trot with ne’er a tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as two and fifty horses. Why, nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Petruchio, since we are stepp’d thus far in,
I will continue that I broach’d in jest.
I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife
With wealth enough, and young and beauteous,
Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.
Her only fault, and that is faults enough,
Is that she is intolerable curst
And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure,
That were my state far worser than it is,
I would not wed her for a mine of gold.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Hortensio, peace! Thou know’st not gold’s effect.
Tell me her father’s name, and ’tis enough;
For I will board her, though she chide as loud
As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Her father is Baptista Minola,
An affable and courteous gentleman.
Her name is Katherina Minola,
Renown’d in Padua for her scolding tongue.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I know her father, though I know not her,
And he knew my deceased father well.
I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her,
And therefore let me be thus bold with you
To give you over at this first encounter,
Unless you will accompany me thither.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, let him go while the humor lasts. A’ my word, and she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him. She may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so. Why, that’s nothing; and he begin once, he’ll rail in his rope-tricks. I’ll tell you what, sir, and she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face, and so disfigure her with it, that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat. You know him not, sir.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee,
For in Baptista’s keep my treasure is.
He hath the jewel of my life in hold,
His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca,
And her withholds from me and other more,
Suitors to her and rivals in my love;
Supposing it a thing impossible,
For those defects I have before rehears’d,
That ever Katherina will be woo’d.
Therefore this order hath Baptista ta’en,
That none shall have access unto Bianca
Till Katherine the curst have got a husband.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Katherine the curst!
A title for a maid of all titles the worst.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace,
And offer me disguis’d in sober robes
To old Baptista as a schoolmaster
Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca,
That so I may by this device at least
Have leave and leisure to make love to her,
And unsuspected court her by herself.

stagedir.dir: Enter Gremio, and Lucentio disguised as a schoolmaster.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: O, very well, I have perus’d the note.
Hark you, sir, I’ll have them very fairly bound—
All books of love, see that at any hand—
And see you read no other lectures to her.
You understand me. Over and beside
Signior Baptista’s liberality,
I’ll mend it with a largess. Take your paper too,
And let me have them very well perfum’d;
For she is sweeter than perfume itself
To whom they go to. What will you read to her?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: What e’er I read to her, I’ll plead for you
As for my patron, stand you so assur’d,
As firmly as yourself were still in place,
Yea, and perhaps with more successful words
Than you—unless you were a scholar, sir.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: O this learning, what a thing it is!

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: O this woodcock, what an ass it is!

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Peace, sirrah!

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Grumio, mum!
God save you, Signior Gremio.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.
Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola.
I promis’d to inquire carefully
About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca,
And by good fortune I have lighted well
On this young man; for learning and behavior
Fit for her turn, well read in poetry
And other books, good ones, I warrant ye.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: ’Tis well; and I have met a gentleman
Hath promis’d me to help me to another,
A fine musician to instruct our mistress;
So shall I no whit be behind in duty
To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Beloved of me, and that my deeds shall prove.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: And that his bags shall prove.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Gremio, ’tis now no time to vent our love;
Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,
I’ll tell you news indifferent good for either,
Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,
Upon agreement from us to his liking,
Will undertake to woo curst Katherine,
Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: So said, so done, is well.
Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I know she is an irksome brawling scold.
If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: No, say’st me so, friend? What countryman?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Born in Verona, old Antonio’s son.
My father dead, my fortune lives for me,
And I do hope good days and long to see.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: O sir, such a life, with such a wife, were strange;
But if you have a stomach, to’t a’ God’s name;
You shall have me assisting you in all.
But will you woo this wild-cat?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Will I live?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Will he woo her? Ay—or I’ll hang her.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why came I hither but to that intent?
Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?
Have I not in my time heard lions roar?
Have I not heard the sea, puff’d up with winds,
Rage like an angry boar chafed with sweat?
Have I not heard great ordnance in the field,
And heaven’s artillery thunder in the skies?
Have I not in a pitched battle heard
Loud ’larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets’ clang?
And do you tell me of a woman’s tongue,
That gives not half so great a blow to hear
As will a chestnut in a farmer’s fire?
Tush, tush, fear boys with bugs.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: For he fears none.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Hortensio, hark.
This gentleman is happily arriv’d,
My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: I promis’d we would be contributors,
And bear his charge of wooing, whatsoe’er.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: And so we will, provided that he win her.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.

stagedir.dir: Enter Tranio brave, as Lucentio, and Biondello.

scene.line: Well begun, Tranio.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Sir, a word ere you go.
Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: And if I be, sir, is it any offense?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: No; if without more words you will get you hence.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free
For me as for you?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: But so is not she.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: For what reason, I beseech you?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: For this reason, if you’ll know,
That she’s the choice love of Signior Gremio.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: That she’s the chosen of Signior Hortensio.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Softly, my masters! If you be gentlemen,
Do me this right: hear me with patience.
Baptista is a noble gentleman,
To whom my father is not all unknown,
And were his daughter fairer than she is,
She may more suitors have, and me for one.
Fair Leda’s daughter had a thousand wooers,
Then well one more may fair Bianca have;
And so she shall. Lucentio shall make one,
Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: What, this gentleman will out-talk us all.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Sir, give him head, I know he’ll prove a jade.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,
Did you yet ever see Baptista’s daughter?

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: No, sir, but hear I do that he hath two:
The one as famous for a scolding tongue,
As is the other for beauteous modesty.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Sir, sir, the first’s for me, let her go by.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules,
And let it be more than Alcides’ twelve.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Sir, understand you this of me, in sooth:
The youngest daughter, whom you hearken for,
Her father keeps from all access of suitors,
And will not promise her to any man,
Until the elder sister first be wed.
The younger then is free, and not before.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: If it be so, sir, that you are the man
Must stead us all, and me amongst the rest;
And if you break the ice, and do this feat,
Achieve the elder, set the younger free
For our access—whose hap shall be to have her
Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive,
And since you do profess to be a suitor,
You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman,
To whom we all rest generally beholding.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Sir, I shall not be slack; in sign whereof,
Please ye we may contrive this afternoon,
And quaff carouses to our mistress’ health,
And do as adversaries do in law,
Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.

speech.speaker: GRU., BION.
speech.line: O excellent motion! Fellows, let’s be gone.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: The motion’s good indeed, and be it so,
Petruchio, I shall be your ben venuto.

scene.scenelocation: Padua. A room in Baptista Minola’s house.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: What, will you not suffer me? Nay, now I see
She is your treasure, she must have a husband;
I must dance barefoot on her wedding-day,
And for your love to her lead apes in hell.
Talk not to me, I will go sit and weep,
Till I can find occasion of revenge.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Good morrow, neighbor Baptista.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Good morrow, neighbor Gremio. God save you, gentlemen!

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: And you, good sir! Pray have you not a daughter
Call’d Katherina, fair and virtuous?

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I have a daughter, sir, call’d Katherina.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: You are too blunt, go to it orderly.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: You wrong me, Signior Gremio, give me leave.
I am a gentleman of Verona, sir,
That hearing of her beauty and her wit,
Her affability and bashful modesty,
Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior,
Am bold to show myself a forward guest
Within your house, to make mine eye the witness
Of that report which I so oft have heard.
And for an entrance to my entertainment,
I do present you with a man of mine,
Cunning in music and the mathematics,
To instruct her fully in those sciences,
Whereof I know she is not ignorant.
Accept of him, or else you do me wrong.
His name is Litio, born in Mantua.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Y’ are welcome, sir, and he, for your good sake.
But for my daughter Katherine, this I know,
She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I see you do not mean to part with her,
Or else you like not of my company.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Mistake me not, I speak but as I find.
Whence are you, sir? What may I call your name?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Petruchio is my name, Antonio’s son,
A man well known throughout all Italy.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I know him well; you are welcome for his sake.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray
Let us that are poor petitioners speak too.
Backare! You are marvellous forward.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: I doubt it not, sir; but you will curse your wooing.
Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it. To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar,
that hath been long studying at Rheims, as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the other in music and mathematics. His name is Cambio; pray accept his service.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio.
Sirrah, lead these gentlemen
To my daughters, and tell them both,
These are their tutors. Bid them use them well.

stagedir.dir: Exit Baptista’s Servant with Lucentio and Hortensio, Biondello following.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: How now, my friend, why dost thou look so pale?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: I think she’ll sooner prove a soldier,
Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Why then thou canst not break her to the lute?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Why no, for she hath broke the lute to me.
I did but tell her she mistook her frets,
And bow’d her hand to teach her fingering;
When, with a most impatient devilish spirit,
“Frets, call you these?” quoth she, “I’ll fume with them.”
And with that word she strook me on the head,
And through the instrument my pate made way,
And there I stood amazed for a while,
As on a pillory, looking through the lute,
While she did call me rascal fiddler
And twangling Jack, with twenty such vild terms,
As had she studied to misuse me so.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Now by the world, it is a lusty wench!
I love her ten times more than e’er I did.
O, how I long to have some chat with her!

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited.
Proceed in practice with my younger daughter;
She’s apt to learn, and thankful for good turns.
Signior Petruchio, will you go with us,
Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I pray you do. I’ll attend her here,

stagedir.dir: Exit Baptista with Gremio, Tranio, and Hortensio. Manet Petruchio.

speech.line: Good morrow, Kate, for that’s your name, I hear.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing:
They call me Katherine that do talk of me.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: You lie, in faith, for you are call’d plain Kate,
And bonny Kate, and sometimes Kate the curst;
But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom,
Kate of Kate-Hall, my super-dainty Kate,
For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate,
Take this of me, Kate of my consolation—
Hearing thy mildness prais’d in every town,
Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,
Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs,
Myself am mov’d to woo thee for my wife.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Mov’d! In good time! Let him that mov’d you hither
Remove you hence. I knew you at the first
You were a moveable.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why, what’s a moveable?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: A join’d-stool.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Thou hast hit it; come sit on me.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Alas, good Kate, I will not burden thee,
For knowing thee to be but young and light.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Too light for such a swain as you to catch,
And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Should be! Should—buzz!

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Well ta’en, and like a buzzard.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: O slow-wing’d turtle, shall a buzzard take thee?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Come, come, you wasp, i’ faith you are too angry.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: My remedy is then to pluck it out.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?
In his tail.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: In his tongue.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Whose tongue?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Yours, if you talk of tales, and so farewell.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: What, with my tongue in your tail? Nay, come again,
Good Kate; I am a gentleman—

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: That I’ll try.
Here comes your father. Never make denial;
I must and will have Katherine to my wife.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: How but well, sir? How but well?
It were impossible I should speed amiss.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Why, how now, daughter Katherine, in your dumps?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Call you me daughter? Now I promise you
You have show’d a tender fatherly regard,
To wish me wed to one half lunatic,
A madcap ruffian and a swearing Jack,
That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Father, ’tis thus: yourself and all the world,
That talk’d of her, have talk’d amiss of her.
If she be curst, it is for policy,
For she’s not froward, but modest as the dove;
She is not hot, but temperate as the morn;
For patience she will prove a second Grissel,
And Roman Lucrece for her chastity;
And to conclude, we have ’greed so well together
That upon Sunday is the wedding-day.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: I’ll see thee hang’d on Sunday first.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Hark, Petruchio, she says she’ll see thee hang’d first.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Is this your speeding? Nay then good night our part!

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Be patient, gentlemen, I choose her for myself.
If she and I be pleas’d, what’s that to you?
’Tis bargain’d ’twixt us twain, being alone,
That she shall still be curst in company.
I tell you ’tis incredible to believe
How much she loves me. O, the kindest Kate,
She hung about my neck, and kiss on kiss
She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath,
That in a twink she won me to her love.
O, you are novices! ’tis a world to see
How tame, when men and women are alone,
A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.
Give me thy hand, Kate, I will unto Venice
To buy apparel ’gainst the wedding-day.
Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests,
I will be sure my Katherine shall be fine.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I know not what to say, but give me your hands.
God send you joy, Petruchio, ’tis a match.

speech.speaker: BOTH GRE. AND TRA.
speech.line: Amen, say we. We will be witnesses.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
I will to Venice, Sunday comes apace.
We will have rings and things, and fine array;
And kiss me, Kate, we will be married a’ Sunday.

scene.line: My land amounts not to so much in all.—
That she shall have, besides an argosy
That now is lying in Marsellis road.
What, have I chok’d you with an argosy?

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Gremio, ’tis known my father hath no less
Than three great argosies, besides two galliasses
And twelve tight galleys. These I will assure her,
And twice as much, what e’er thou off’rest next.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Nay, I have off’red all, I have no more,
And she can have no more than all I have;
If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Why then the maid is mine from all the world,
By your firm promise; Gremio is outvied.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I must confess your offer is the best,
And let your father make her the assurance,
She is your own, else you must pardon me;
If you should die before him, where’s her dower?

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: That’s but a cavil; he is old, I young.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: And may not young men die as well as old?

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Well, gentlemen,
I am thus resolv’d: on Sunday next you know
My daughter Katherine is to be married.
Now on the Sunday following shall Bianca
Be bride to you, if you make this assurance;
If not, to Signior Gremio.
And so I take my leave, and thank you both.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide!
Yet I have fac’d it with a card of ten.
’Tis in my head to do my master good.
I see no reason but suppos’d Lucentio
Must get a father, call’d suppos’d Vincentio;
And that’s a wonder. Fathers commonly
Do get their children; but in this case of wooing,
A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Fiddler, forbear, you grow too forward, sir.
Have you so soon forgot the entertainment
Her sister Katherine welcom’d you withal?

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: But, wrangling pedant, this is
The patroness of heavenly harmony.
Then give me leave to have prerogative,
And when in music we have spent an hour,
Your lecture shall have leisure for as much.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Preposterous ass, that never read so far
To know the cause why music was ordain’d!
Was it not to refresh the mind of man
After his studies or his usual pain?
Then give me leave to read philosophy,
And while I pause, serve in your harmony.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Sirrah, I will not bear these braves of thine.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Why, gentlemen, you do me double wrong
To strive for that which resteth in my choice.
I am no breeching scholar in the schools,
I’ll not be tied to hours, nor ’pointed times,
But learn my lessons as I please myself.
And to cut off all strife, here sit we down:
Take you your instrument, play you the whiles,
His lecture will be done ere you have tun’d.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: You’ll leave his lecture when I am in tune?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: That will be never, tune your instrument.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Where left we last?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Here, madam:

line.latin: “Hic ibat Simois; hic est Sigeia tellus;
Hic steterat Priami regia celsa senis.”

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Construe them.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: “Hic ibat,” as I told you before, “Simois,” I am Lucentio, “hic est,” son unto Vincentio of Pisa, “Sigeia tellus,” disguis’d thus to get your love, “Hic steterat,” and that Lucentio that comes a-wooing, “Priami,” is my man Tranio, “regia,” bearing my port, “celsa senis,” that we might beguile the old pantaloon.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Madam, my instrument’s in tune.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Let’s hear. O fie, the treble jars.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Spit in the hole, man, and tune again.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Now let me see if I can construe it: “Hic ibat Simois,” I know you not, “hic est Sigeia tellus,” I trust you not, “Hic steterat Priami,” take heed he hear us not, “regia,” presume not, “celsa senis,” despair not.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Madam, ’tis now in tune.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: All but the base.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: The base is right, ’tis the base knave that jars.
You may go walk, and give me leave a while;
My lessons make no music in three parts.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Are you so formal, sir? Well, I must wait,

line.recite: “Gamut I am, the ground of all accord:
A re, to plead Hortensio’s passion;
B mi, Bianca, take him for thy lord,
C fa ut, that loves with all affection.
D sol re, one cliff, two notes have I,
E la mi, show pity, or I die.”

speech.line: Call you this gamut? Tut, I like it not.
Old fashions please me best; I am not so nice
To change true rules for odd inventions.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.

stagedir.dir: Enter Baptista, Gremio, Tranio as Lucentio, Katherine, Bianca, Lucentio as Cambio, and others, attendants.

scene.line: Signior Lucentio, this is the ’pointed day,
That Katherine and Petruchio should be married,
And yet we hear not of our son-in-law.
What will be said? What mockery will it be,
To want the bridegroom when the priest attends
To speak the ceremonial rites of marriage?
What says Lucentio to this shame of ours?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: No shame but mine. I must forsooth be forc’d
To give my hand oppos’d against my heart
Unto a mad-brain rudesby full of spleen,
Who woo’d in haste, and means to wed at leisure.
I told you, I, he was a frantic fool,
Hiding his bitter jests in blunt behavior;
And to be noted for a merry man,
He’ll woo a thousand, ’point the day of marriage,
Make friends, invite, and proclaim the banes,
Yet never means to wed where he hath woo’d.
Now must the world point at poor Katherine,
And say, “Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife,
If it would please him come and marry her!”

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Patience, good Katherine, and Baptista too.
Upon my life, Petruchio means but well,
Whatever fortune stays him from his word.
Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;
Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Would Katherine had never seen him though!

stagedir.dir: Exit weeping followed by Bianca and others.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Master, master, news, old news, and such news as you never heard of!

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Is it new and old too? How may that be?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio’s coming?

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Is he come?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Why, no, sir.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: He is coming.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: When will he be here?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: When he stands where I am, and sees you there.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: But say, what to thine old news?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Why, Petruchio is coming in a new hat and an old jerkin; a pair of old breeches thrice turn’d; a pair of boots that have been candle-cases, one buckled, another lac’d; an old rusty sword ta’en out of the town armory, with a broken hilt, and chapeless; with two broken points; his horse hipp’d, with an old mothy saddle and stirrups of no kindred; besides, possess’d with the glanders and like to mose in the chine, troubled with the lampass, infected with the fashions, full of windgalls, sped with spavins, ray’d with the yellows, past cure of the fives, stark spoil’d with the staggers, begnawn with the bots, sway’d in the back, and shoulder-shotten, near-legg’d before, and with a half-cheek’d bit and a head-stall of sheep’s leather, which being restrain’d to keep him from stumbling, hath been often burst, and now repair’d with knots; one girth six times piec’d, and a woman’s crupper of velure, which hath two letters for her name fairly set down in studs, and here and there piec’d with packthread.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Who comes with him?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: O, sir, his lackey, for all the world caparison’d like the horse; with a linen stock on one leg, and a kersey boot-hose on the other, gart’red with a red and blue list; an old hat, and the humor of forty fancies prick’d in’t for a feather: a monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman’s lackey.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: ’Tis some odd humor pricks him to this fashion;
Yet oftentimes he goes but mean apparell’d.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I am glad he’s come, howsoe’er he comes.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Why, sir, he comes not.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Didst thou not say he comes?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Who? That Petruchio came?

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Ay, that Petruchio came.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Why, that’s all one.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Nay, by Saint Jamy,
I hold you a penny,
A horse and a man
Is more than one,
And yet not many.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: He hath some meaning in his mad attire.
We will persuade him, be it possible,
To put on better ere he go to church.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I’ll after him, and see the event of this.

scene.line: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: As willingly as e’er I came from school.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: And is the bride and bridegroom coming home?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: A bridegroom, say you? ’Tis a groom indeed,
A grumbling groom, and that the girl shall find.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Curster than she? Why, ’tis impossible.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Why, he’s a devil, a devil, a very fiend.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Why, she’s a devil, a devil, the devil’s dam.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Tut, she’s a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!
I’ll tell you, Sir Lucentio: when the priest
Should ask if Katherine should be his wife,
“Ay, by gogs-wouns,” quoth he, and swore so loud,
That all amaz’d the priest let fall the book,
And as he stoop’d again to take it up,
This mad-brain’d bridegroom took him such a cuff
That down fell priest and book, and book and priest.
“Now take them up,” quoth he, “if any list.”

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: What said the wench when he rose again?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp’d and swore
As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
But after many ceremonies done,
He calls for wine. “A health!” quoth he, as if
He had been aboard, carousing to his mates
After a storm, quaff’d off the muscadel,
And threw the sops all in the sexton’s face,
Having no other reason
But that his beard grew thin and hungerly,
And seem’d to ask him sops as he was drinking.
This done, he took the bride about the neck,
And kiss’d her lips with such a clamorous smack
That at the parting all the church did echo.
And I seeing this, came thence for very shame,
And after me I know the rout is coming.
Such a mad marriage never was before.
Hark, hark, I hear the minstrels play.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains.
I know you think to dine with me today,
And have prepared great store of wedding cheer,
But so it is, my haste doth call me hence,
And therefore here I mean to take my leave.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Is’t possible you will away tonight?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I must away today, before night come.
Make it no wonder; if you knew my business,
You would entreat me rather go than stay.
And, honest company, I thank you all
That have beheld me give away myself
To this most patient, sweet, and virtuous wife.
Dine with my father, drink a health to me,
For I must hence, and farewell to you all.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Let us entreat you stay till after dinner.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: It may not be.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Let me entreat you.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: It cannot be.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Let me entreat you.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I am content.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Are you content to stay?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I am content you shall entreat me stay,
But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Now if you love me stay.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Grumio, my horse.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Ay, sir, they be ready; the oats have eaten the horses.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Nay then,
Do what thou canst, I will not go today,
No, nor tomorrow—not till I please myself.
The door is open, sir, there lies your way;
You may be jogging whiles your boots are green.
For me, I’ll not be gone till I please myself.
’Tis like you’ll prove a jolly surly groom,
That take it on you at the first so roundly.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: O Kate, content thee, prithee be not angry.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: I will be angry; what hast thou to do?
Father, be quiet, he shall stay my leisure.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.
I see a woman may be made a fool,
If she had not a spirit to resist.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: They shall go forward, Kate, at thy command.
Obey the bride, you that attend on her.
Go to the feast, revel and domineer,
Carouse full measure to her maidenhead,
Be mad and merry, or go hang yourselves;
But for my bonny Kate, she must with me.
Nay, look not big, nor stamp, nor stare, nor fret,
I will be master of what is mine own.
She is my goods, my chattels, she is my house,
My household stuff, my field, my barn,
My horse, my ox, my ass, my any thing;
And here she stands, touch her whoever dare,
I’ll bring mine action on the proudest he
That stops my way in Padua. Grumio,
Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves;
Rescue thy mistress if thou be a man
Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch thee, Kate!
I’ll buckler thee against a million.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Fie, fie on all tir’d jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? Was ever man so ray’d? Was ever man so weary? I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them. Now were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me. But I with blowing the fire shall warm myself; for considering the weather, a taller man than I will take cold. Holla, ho, Curtis!

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: This ’tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: And therefore ’tis call’d a sensible tale; and this cuff was but to knock at your ear, and beseech list’ning. Now I begin: Inprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress—

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: Both of one horse?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: What’s that to thee?

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: Why, a horse.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Tell thou the tale. But hadst thou not cross’d me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell, and she under her horse; thou shouldst have heard in how miry a place, how she was bemoil’d, how he left her with the horse upon her, how he beat me because her horse stumbled, how she waded through the dirt to pluck him off me; how he swore, how she pray’d that never pray’d before; how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her bridle was burst; how I lost my crupper, with many things of worthy memory, which now shall die in oblivion, and thou return unexperienc’d to thy grave.

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: By this reck’ning he is more shrew than she.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Ay, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home. But what talk I of this? Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest; let their heads be slickly comb’d, their blue coats brush’d, and their garters of an indifferent knit; let them curtsy with their left legs, and not presume to touch a hair of my master’s horse-tail till they kiss their hands. Are they all ready?

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: They are.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Call them forth.

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: Do you hear, ho? You must meet my master to countenance my mistress.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Why, she hath a face of her own.

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: Who knows not that?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.

speech.speaker: CURT.
speech.line: I call them forth to credit her.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Where be these knaves? What, no man at door
To hold my stirrup, nor to take my horse?
Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?

speech.speaker: ALL. SERV.
speech.line: Here, here, sir, here, sir.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Here, sir! Here, sir! Here, sir! Here, sir!
You loggerheaded and unpolish’d grooms!
What? No attendance? No regard? No duty?
Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Here, sir, as foolish as I was before.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: You peasant swain, you whoreson malt-horse drudge!
Did I not bid thee meet me in the park,
And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Nathaniel’s coat, sir, was not fully made,
And Gabr’el’s pumps were all unpink’d i’ th’ heel;
There was no link to color Peter’s hat,
And Walter’s dagger was not come from sheathing;
There were none fine but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory;
The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly,
Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.
“Where is the life that late I led?
Where are those”—
Sit down, Kate, and welcome. Soud, soud, soud, soud!
“It was the friar of orders grey,
As he forth walked on his way”—
Out, you rogue, you pluck my foot awry.
Take that, and mend the plucking off the other.
Where’s my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence,
And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither;
One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.
Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water?
Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.
You whoreson villain, will you let it fall?

scene.line: You heedless joltheads and unmanner’d slaves!
What, do you grumble? I’ll be with you straight.

speech.speaker: NATH.
speech.line: Peter, didst ever see the like?

speech.speaker: PETER.
speech.line: He kills her in her own humor.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Thus have I politicly begun my reign,
And ’tis my hope to end successfully.
My falcon now is sharp and passing empty,
And till she stoop, she must not be full-gorg’d,
For then she never looks upon her lure.
Another way I have to man my haggard,
To make her come, and know her keeper’s call,
That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites
That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
She eat no meat today, nor none shall eat;
Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not;
As with the meat, some undeserved fault
I’ll find about the making of the bed,
And here I’ll fling the pillow, there the bolster,
This way the coverlet, another way the sheets.
Ay, and amid this hurly I intend
That all is done in reverend care of her,
And in conclusion, she shall watch all night,
And if she chance to nod I’ll rail and brawl,
And with the clamor keep her still awake.
This is a way to kill a wife with kindness,
And thus I’ll curb her mad and headstrong humor.
He that knows better how to tame a shrew,
Now let him speak; ’tis charity to shew.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Is’t possible, friend Litio, that Mistress Bianca
Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?
I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,
Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: What, master, read you? First resolve me that.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Quick proceeders, marry! Now tell me, I pray,
You that durst swear that your mistress Bianca
Lov’d none in the world so well as Lucentio.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: O despiteful love, unconstant womankind!
I tell thee, Litio, this is wonderful.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Mistake no more, I am not Litio,
Nor a musician, as I seem to be,
But one that scorn to live in this disguise
For such a one as leaves a gentleman,
And makes a god of such a cullion.
Know, sir, that I am call’d Hortensio.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Signior Hortensio, I have often heard
Of your entire affection to Bianca,
And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,
I will with you, if you be so contented,
Forswear Bianca and her love forever.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: See how they kiss and court! Signior Lucentio,
Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow
Never to woo her more, but do forswear her
As one unworthy all the former favors
That I have fondly flatter’d her withal.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: And here I take the like unfeigned oath,
Never to marry with her though she would entreat.
Fie on her, see how beastly she doth court him!

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,
I will be married to a wealthy widow,
Ere three days pass, which hath as long lov’d me
As I have lov’d this proud disdainful haggard.
And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.
Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,
Shall win my love, and so I take my leave,
In resolution as I swore before.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: O master, master, I have watch’d so long
That I am dog-weary, but at last I spied
An ancient angel coming down the hill,
Will serve the turn.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: What is he, Biondello?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Master, a marcantant, or a pedant,
I know not what, but formal in apparel,
In gait and countenance surely like a father.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: And what of him, Tranio?

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: If he be credulous, and trust my tale,
I’ll make him glad to seem Vincentio,
And give assurance to Baptista Minola,
As if he were the right Vincentio.
Take in your love, and then let me alone.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: God save you, sir!

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: And you, sir! You are welcome.
Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two,
But then up farther, and as far as Rome,
And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: What countryman, I pray?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Of Mantua.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Of Mantua, sir? Marry, God forbid!
And come to Padua, careless of your life?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: My life, sir? How, I pray? For that goes hard.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: ’Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?
Your ships are stay’d at Venice, and the Duke,
For private quarrel ’twixt your Duke and him,
Hath publish’d and proclaim’d it openly.
’Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come,
You might have heard it else proclaim’d about.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Alas, sir, it is worse for me than so,
For I have bills for money by exchange
From Florence, and must here deliver them.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Well, sir, to do you courtesy,
This will I do, and this I will advise you.
First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,
Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Among them know you one Vincentio?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: I know him not, but I have heard of him;
A merchant of incomparable wealth.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: He is my father, sir, and sooth to say,
In count’nance somewhat doth resemble you.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: To save your life in this extremity,
This favor will I do you for his sake;
And think it not the worst of all your fortunes
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credit shall you undertake,
And in my house you shall be friendly lodg’d.
Look that you take upon you as you should;
You understand me, sir? So shall you stay
Till you have done your business in the city.
If this be court’sy, sir, accept of it.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever
The patron of my life and liberty.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Then go with me to make the matter good.
This by the way I let you understand:
My father is here look’d for every day,
To pass assurance of a dow’r in marriage
’Twixt me and one Baptista’s daughter here.
In all these circumstances I’ll instruct you;
Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.

scene.line: That feed’st me with the very name of meat.
Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you
That triumph thus upon my misery!
Go get thee gone, I say.

stagedir.dir: Enter Petruchio and Hortensio with meat.

scene.line: Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me.—
Much good do it unto thy gentle heart!
Kate, eat apace. And now, my honey love,
Will we return unto thy father’s house,
And revel it as bravely as the best,
With silken coats and caps, and golden rings,
With ruffs and cuffs, and fardingales, and things,
With scarfs and fans, and double change of brav’ry,
With amber bracelets, beads, and all this knav’ry.
What, hast thou din’d? The tailor stays thy leisure,
To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure.
What news with you, sir?

speech.speaker: HAB.
speech.line: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why, this was moulded on a porringer—
A velvet dish. Fie, fie, ’tis lewd and filthy.
Why, ’tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,
A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby’s cap.
Away with it! Come let me have a bigger.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: I’ll have no bigger, this doth fit the time,
And gentlewomen wear such caps as these.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: When you are gentle, you shall have one too,
And not till then.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: That will not be in haste.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak,
And speak I will. I am no child, no babe;
Your betters have endur’d me say my mind,
And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or else my heart concealing it will break,
And rather than it shall, I will be free,
Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why, thou say’st true, it is a paltry cap,
A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie.
I love thee well in that thou lik’st it not.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Love me, or love me not, I like the cap,
And it I will have, or I will have none.

scene.line: I see she’s like to have neither cap nor gown.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: You bid me make it orderly and well,
According to the fashion and the time.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Marry, and did; but if you be rememb’red,
I did not bid you mar it to the time.
Go hop me over every kennel home,
For you shall hop without my custom, sir.
I’ll none of it; hence, make your best of it.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: I never saw a better fashion’d gown,
More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable.
Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why, true, he means to make a puppet of thee.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble,
Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!
Brav’d in mine own house with a skein of thread?
Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant,
Or I shall so bemete thee with thy yard
As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou liv’st!
I tell thee, I, that thou hast marr’d her gown.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: Your worship is deceiv’d, the gown is made
Just as my master had direction.
Grumio gave order how it should be done.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: I gave him no order, I gave him the stuff.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: But how did you desire it should be made?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: But did you not request to have it cut?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Thou hast fac’d many things.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: I have.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Face not me; thou hast brav’d many men, brave not me; I will neither be fac’d nor brav’d. I say unto thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown, but I did not bid him cut it to pieces. Ergo, thou liest.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Read it.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: The note lies in ’s throat if he say I said so.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: I confess the cape.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Ay, there’s the villainy.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Error i’ th’ bill, sir, error i’ th’ bill! I commanded the sleeves should be cut out, and sew’d up again, and that I’ll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be arm’d in a thimble.

speech.speaker: TAI.
speech.line: This is true that I say; and I had thee in place where, thou shouldst know it.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: I am for thee straight. Take thou the bill, give me thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: God-a-mercy, Grumio, then he shall have no odds.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: You are i’ th’ right, sir, ’tis for my mistress.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Go take it up unto thy master’s use.

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: Villain, not for thy life! Take up my mistress’ gown for thy master’s use!

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why, sir, what’s your conceit in that?

speech.speaker: GRU.
speech.line: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for:
Take up my mistress’ gown to his master’s use!
O fie, fie, fie!

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.—
Go take it hence, be gone, and say no more.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Tailor, I’ll pay thee for thy gown tomorrow,
Take no unkindness of his hasty words
Away, I say, commend me to thy master.

scene.line: Why, so this gallant will command the sun.

stagedir.dir: Enter Tranio as Lucentio, and the Pedant dress’d like Vincentio, booted and bare-headed.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Sir, this is the house, please it you that I call?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Ay, what else? And but I be deceived,
Signior Baptista may remember me
Near twenty years ago in Genoa,
Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: ’Tis well, and hold your own in any case
With such austerity as ’longeth to a father.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: I warrant you. But, sir, here comes your boy;
’Twere good he were school’d.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,
Now do your duty throughly, I advise you.
Imagine ’twere the right Vincentio.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Tut, fear not me.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you look’d for him this day in Padua.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Th’ art a tall fellow; hold thee that to drink.
Here comes Baptista; set your countenance, sir.

stagedir.dir: Enter Baptista and Lucentio as Cambio.

speech.line: Signior Baptista, you are happily met.
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of.
I pray you stand good father to me now,
Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Soft, son!
Sir, by your leave, having come to Padua
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a weighty cause
Of love between your daughter and himself;
And for the good report I hear of you,
And for the love he beareth to your daughter,
And she to him, to stay him not too long,
I am content, in a good father’s care,
To have him match’d; and if you please to like
No worse than I, upon some agreement
Me shall you find ready and willing
With one consent to have her so bestowed;
For curious I cannot be with you,
Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say—
Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
Right true it is, your son Lucentio here
Doth love my daughter, and she loveth him,
Or both dissemble deeply their affections;
And therefore if you say no more than this,
That like a father you will deal with him,
And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done:
Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best
We be affied and such assurance ta’en
As shall with either part’s agreement stand?

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know
Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants;
Besides, old Gremio is heark’ning still,
And happily we might be interrupted.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Then at my lodging, and it like you.
There doth my father lie; and there this night
We’ll pass the business privately and well.
Send for your daughter by your servant here;
My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.
The worst is this, that at so slender warning,
You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: It likes me well. Cambio, hie you home,
And bid Bianca make her ready straight;
And if you will, tell what hath happened:
Lucentio’s father is arriv’d in Padua,
And how she’s like to be Lucentio’s wife.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.
Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?
Welcome! One mess is like to be your cheer.
Come, sir, we will better it in Pisa.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: I follow you.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lucentio as Cambio and Biondello.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Cambio!

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: What say’st thou, Biondello?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Biondello, what of that?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Faith, nothing; but h’as left me here behind to expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I pray thee moralize them.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: And what of him?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: And then?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: The old priest of Saint Luke’s church is at your command at all hours.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: And what of all this?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: I cannot tell, except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance. Take you assurance of her, cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum; to th’ church take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses.
If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say,
But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Hear’st thou, Biondello?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: I cannot tarry. I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit, and so may you, sir. And so adieu, sir; my master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke’s to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I may and will, if she be so contented.
She will be pleas’d, then wherefore should I doubt?
Hap what hap may, I’ll roundly go about her;
It shall go hard if Cambio go without her.

stagedir.dir: Enter Petruchio, Kate, Hortensio, and Servants.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.
Have to my widow! And if she be froward,
Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I fly, Biondello; but they may chance to need thee at home, therefore leave us.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Nay, faith, I’ll see the church a’ your back, and then come back to my master’s as soon as I can.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Sir, here’s the door, this is Lucentio’s house.
My father’s bears more toward the market-place;
Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: You shall not choose but drink before you go.
I think I shall command your welcome here;
And by all likelihood some cheer is toward.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: They’re busy within, you were best knock louder.

stagedir.dir: Pedant looks out of the window.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: What’s he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: He’s within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to make merry withal?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself, he shall need none so long as I live.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Nay, I told you your son was well belov’d in Padua. Do you hear, sir?—to leave frivolous circumstances, I pray you tell Signior Lucentio that his father is come from Pisa, and is here at the door to speak with him.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Thou liest, his father is come from Padua and here looking out at the window.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Art thou his father?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Ay, sir, so his mother says, if I may believe her.

speech.speaker: PET.
BION.
speech.line: I have seen them in the church together, God send ’em good shipping! But who is here? Mine old master Vincentio! Now we are undone and brought to nothing.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Come hither, crack-hemp.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: I hope I may choose, sir.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Forgot you? No, sir. I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy master’s father, Vincentio?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: What, my old worshipful old master? Yes, marry, sir—see where he looks out of the window.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Is’t so indeed?

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Help, son! Help, Signior Baptista!

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Prithee, Kate, let’s stand aside and see the end of this controversy.

stagedir.dir: Enter Pedant below with Servants, Baptista, Tranio as Lucentio.

speech.line: Carry this mad knave to the jail. Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Carry me to the jail?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Stay, officer, he shall not go to prison.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Talk not, Signior Gremio; I say he shall go to prison.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catch’d in this business. I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.

speech.speaker: PED.
speech.line: Swear if thou dar’st.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Nay, I dare not swear it.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Away with the dotard, to the jail with him!

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Pardon, sweet father.

speech.speaker: LORD.
speech.line: Lives my sweet son?

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Pardon, dear father.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: How hast thou offended?
Where is Lucentio?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Here’s Lucentio,
Right son to the right Vincentio,
That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit supposes blear’d thine eyne.

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Here’s packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Where is that damned villain Tranio,
That fac’d and braved me in this matter so?

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Cambio is chang’d into Lucentio.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca’s love
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did bear my countenance in the town,
And happily I have arrived at the last
Unto the wished haven of my bliss.
What Tranio did, myself enforc’d him to;
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: I’ll slit the villain’s nose, that would have sent me to the jail.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: But do you hear, sir? Have you married my daughter without asking my good will?

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: Fear not, Baptista, we will content you, go to; but I will in to be reveng’d for this villainy.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Look not pale, Bianca, thy father will not frown.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Husband, let’s follow, to see the end of this ado.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: What, in the midst of the street?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: What, art thou asham’d of me?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: No, sir, God forbid, but asham’d to kiss.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why then let’s home again. Come, sirrah, let’s away.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Nay, I will give thee a kiss; now pray thee, love, stay.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:
Better once than never, for never too late.

stagedir.dir: Enter Baptista, Vincentio, Gremio, the Pedant, Lucentio, and Bianca; Petruchio, Katherina, Hortensio, Tranio, Biondello, Grumio, and Widow: the servingmen with Tranio bringing in a banquet.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio,
This bird you aim’d at, though you hit her not;
Therefore a health to all that shot and miss’d.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: O, sir, Lucentio slipp’d me like his greyhound,
Which runs himself, and catches for his master.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: A good swift simile, but something currish.

speech.speaker: TRA.
speech.line: ’Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself;
’Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: O, O, Petruchio, Tranio hits you now.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: ’A has a little gall’d me, I confess;
And as the jest did glance away from me,
’Tis ten to one it maim’d you two outright.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Now in good sadness, son Petruchio,
I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Well, I say no; and therefore for assurance
Let’s each one send unto his wife,
And he whose wife is most obedient,
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Content. What’s the wager?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Twenty crowns.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Twenty crowns!
I’ll venture so much of my hawk or hound,
But twenty times so much upon my wife.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: A hundred then.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Content.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: A match! ’Tis done.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Who shall begin?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: That will I.
Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: I go.

scene.line: How now, what news?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: Sir, my mistress sends you word
That she is busy, and she cannot come.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: How? She is busy, and she cannot come!
Is that an answer?

speech.speaker: GRE.
speech.line: Ay, and a kind one too.
Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I hope better.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife
To come to me forthwith.

scene.line: Now, where’s my wife?

speech.speaker: BION.
speech.line: She says you have some goodly jest in hand.
She will not come; she bids you come to her.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,
Intolerable, not to be endur’d!
Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress,
Say I command her come to me.

speech.speaker: BAP.
speech.line: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Where is your sister, and Hortensio’s wife?

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Go fetch them hither. If they deny to come,
Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.

scene.line: See where she comes, and brings your froward wives
As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.
Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not;
Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.

speech.speaker: WID.
speech.line: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Fie, what a foolish duty call you this?

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: I would your duty were as foolish too.
The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,
Hath cost me a hundred crowns since supper-time.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: The more fool you for laying on my duty.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Katherine, I charge thee tell these headstrong women
What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

speech.speaker: WID.
speech.line: Come, come, you’re mocking; we will have no telling.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Come on, I say, and first begin with her.

speech.speaker: WID.
speech.line: She shall not.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: I say she shall, and first begin with her.

speech.speaker: KATH.
speech.line: Fie, fie, unknit that threat’ning unkind brow,
And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,
To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.
It blots thy beauty, as frosts do bite the meads,
Confounds thy fame, as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
And in no sense is meet or amiable.
A woman mov’d is like a fountain troubled,
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty,
And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip, or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance; commits his body
To painful labor, both by sea and land;
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
Whilst thou li’st warm at home, secure and safe;
And craves no other tribute at thy hands
But love, fair looks, and true obedience—
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince,
Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
And not obedient to his honest will,
What is she but a foul contending rebel,
And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
I am asham’d that women are so simple
To offer war where they should kneel for peace,
Or seek for rule, supremacy, and sway,
When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.
Why are our bodies soft, and weak, and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions, and our hearts,
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haply more,
To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
But now I see our lances are but straws,
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,
And place your hands below your husband’s foot;
In token of which duty, if he please,
My hand is ready, may it do him ease.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Why, there’s a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: Well, go thy ways, old lad, for thou shalt ha’t.

speech.speaker: VIN.
speech.line: ’Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

speech.speaker: PET.
speech.line: Come, Kate, we’ll to bed.
We three are married, but you two are sped.

speech.speaker: HOR.
speech.line: Now go thy ways, thou hast tam’d a curst shrew.

speech.speaker: LUC.
speech.line: ’Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tam’d so.
